Andrew McDonagh wrote:
> Now the depends part.....
>
> As any class with that amount of methods (00s) is suspect IMO, so I tend
> to wrapper the actual interface/class that I'm trying to use with my own
> much smaller interface - essentially hiding the dependency of the
> ResultSet, CORBA POA, etc from my own code.  My interface/wrapper class
> is then tiny - and so a mocking framework just aint worth it.

The places where I've found mocking frameworks the most useful are:

1) Just getting started on a codebase, using test-driven development.  
As Mr. Rainsberger has mentioned, here JMock's flexibility to name 
methods without defining them can be key.

2) Just getting started on legacy code.  I can often safely introduce a 
seam between two classes by extracting an interface from one, and then 
start characterization tests on the other by mocking the new interface.

[In both of the above cases, I've found that over time, I have fewer and 
fewer mock objects in my tests, and even old tests with mock objects 
start losing them.  I think that as the abstractions get better, it 
becomes easier to think of simple implementations of interfaces that 
look less like mocks, and more like useful objects you could actually 
imagine a client using.]

3) Writing plug-ins.  When the ratio of foreign interfaces to lines of 
new business code gets high enough, I become suspicious of wrapping 
every interface, because then the code begins to look like:

// listener callback
public Result somethingHasChanged(FileChange change) {
   return mySomethingHasChanged(new 
BetterAbstractionForFileChange(change)).asClientResult();
}

Which doesn't actually help the reader understand what's going on.  In 
this case, the mock objects tend to stick around until the plug-in 
starts growing to the size of an application in its own right.

Your mileage may vary.

   David Saff
